content.webTitle: From For Anatole's Tomb by Stéphane Mallarmé

fields.headline: From For Anatole's Tomb by Stéphane Mallarmé
fields.bodyText: In 1879, Mallarmé's eight-year-old son Anatole died after several months of illness. Mallarmé (1842-1898) left 210 sheets of pencilled notes towards a poem about his son's death, which appeared in French in 1961 under the title 'Pour un tombeau d'Anatole', and revealed a largely unknown side of the Symbolist poet. Here we publish an extract from Patrick McGuinness's new translation. child sprung from us both - showing us our ideal, the way - to us! father and mother who in sad existence survive him, like the two extremes - ill-matched in him and sundered from each other - whence his death - abolishing this little child 'self' sick in the springtime dead in the autumn - it's the sun ***** son reabsorbed not gone it is him - or his brother I told him this two brothers - forced back remaining in the womb - sure of myself century will not pass by just to instruct me. fury against the formless ***** we have known through you this 'best of ourselves' which often escapes us - and will be in us - in our acts, now - child, seed idealisation father and mother vowing to have no other child - grave dug by him life stops there · Patrick McGuinness's translation of For Anatole's Tomb is published by Carcanet on June 26.
